div1.p: Carter tries to determine what artifacts and materials about Henry Rose Carter would be appropriate for the Historical Medical Museum.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Henry S. Wellcome, May 1, 1930
div1.opener:
Biographic.
Carter
Wellcome, Dr. Henry S.
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
May 1, 1930.
Dear Doctor Wellcome:
div1.p:
This is being typed in order to spare so busy a man as yourself
the trouble of “decoding” the “Carter chirography.”

I have just returned from Baltimore and shall probably have to go
back again next Monday. During my last stay there I tried to see the
photographer, who took the picture you spoke of having enlarged for
your Historical Medical Museum, but she was away. I shall try again next
week, unless (if you can spare the time for it) you could look over some
other pictures of Father, which I got out of storage in Baltimore, among
them an excellent one taken about the time he published his first article
on the extrinsic incubation of yellow fever. This, as you know, is cited
by Walter Reed as one of the three factors determining the direction of
the experiments of his Board; cf. his Preliminary Note...1901. It would
depend then upon whether you prefer your enlarged picture of Father as
he appeared at this time, or the later one as he looked during and after
his War wormk, the yellow fever control work in Peru and as the author of
his History of Yellow Fever. Naturally, I shall consider it a privelege
to arrange for you to have copies of any and all pictures of Father that
you wish, or of anything else which I can procure for you.

I should like to have a somewhat more definite idea of just what
kind of material you would like, concerning Father for your Museum. Un-
fortunately, moving about as we had to do, on account of Father's work, it
was practically impossible to preserve many tangible things relating to his
life and work. Much then, that, even as a child, I felt should be kept,
was promptly eliminated by Father himself in the intersts of efficiency
and “travelling light.” The same feeling that appears in your delightful
anecdote of “K. of K.”...that “mobile troops”...should be mobile! As you
truly said, Father's interests were “world wide,” but my indices therefor
are mainly more in the nature of data for a biography than for a museum,.
i. e. the contents of the trunks and boxes in storage, which I have just
been assorting, ranged from note books on yellow fever and malaria, maps,
some MS etc. to Greek classics, books on plants and flowers, blocks of
native woods, books and notes on mathematics (he got a scholarship for
work in the fourth dimension) chemistry, psychiatry, many books on history,
exploration, anthropology, poetry and, of course, a preponderance of lit-
erature on yellow fever and malaria. I also came across some of the old
tin dippers, with which he did his personal dipping in his malarial surveys.
His saying: “NNever believe what a man tells you about malaria unless he has
a dipper in his hand,” illustrating his conviction that malarial control could
not be handled from an office.
Would you have any use for anything in the nature of:

list.item:
(c) biographic sketches by Welch: Frost: Gorgas etc. some
published, some unpublished. (No MS).

(f) snap shots taken from time of occupation of Cuba up to
tp
-2-
and including his malaria control work in extra cantonment areas during
World War.

div1.p:
As for his diplomas, honorary degrees etc. the chest in which I
tried to keep most of them is missing from storage. I found a few
scattered ones in trunks and book boxes.

I do hope that there may be a chance of my having the very real
happiness of seeing you again. Your all-too-brief visit last week
brought back to me, not the remembrance, but the actuality of far
horizons, high advanture and noble achievement. Surely such moments
as I owe to you will remain a permanent asset! Equally truly I am ex-
tremely anxious to hear more...much more!...especially about your yellow
fever experiments and about your Museum, which I note that you planned,
as Father did his History of Yellow Fever, beginning “with what you know
perfectly in your own time and so gradually” going “back to the times of
less knowledge. Also, I must learn the ultimate fate of the Indians, of
Metlakahtla!
With all manner of good wishes, I remain,

closer.seg:
P. S. I have not forgotten my promise to give you the MS (which I am
sure I have) of Father's appreciation of Gorgas, written just after the
death of the latter.
